resources.string: Naval
Objectives: \n\n States that, for a ship to float, it must displace a mass of water equal to its own mass.

Objectives: 

 • Enable to distinguish, when the mass of a ship changes, the mass of water displaced changes by an equal amount.
 • Determine the relationship between the displacement and mean draught of a ship by using the graph or scale.



https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ivQzkdGUrnw – Explanation </br> https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=X_6fTJRPOXw – Calculation of Displacementn

Objectives:


• Comprehends why the draught of a ship decreases when it passes from fresh water to seawater and vice versa.
 • Extends knowledge about the use of a hydrometer to find the density of dock water.

Objectives:

 • Differentiates how the chart of zones, areas and seasonal periods is used to find the applicable load line.
 • Differentiates freeboard, measured from the upper edge of the deck line to the water on each side, is used to check that the ship is within its permitted limits of loading.

Objectives: 

 • Define the transverse met centre (M) as the point of intersection of successive buoyancy force vectors as the angle of heel increases by a small angle.
 • Comprehends that, for small angles of heel, M can be considered as a fixed point on the centerline on a diagram of a ship heeled to a small angle indicates G, B, Z and M.

Objectives:


• Recalls how lowering the position of G increases all values of the righting lever and vice versa.
 • Identifies calculations as in the above objective to find the vertical and horizontal shifts of the center of gravity resulting from adding, removing or moving masses.

Objectives:


• Identifies if the point of suspension is moved horizontally, the center of gravity of the ship also moves horizontally.
 • Estimate, by using moments about the keel, the position of G after loading or discharging given masses at stated positions.

Objectives: 


• Comprehends by means of diagrams how the center of gravity of the liquid in a partly filled tank moves during rolling
 • Recall the effects of slack tanks, movement of liquids on GM of a ship

Objectives: 

 • To be able to recall the about trim and how to calculate it using trim tables
 • Identifies what are the factors affecting it
Objective: \n\n • Distinguish the general arrangements on different types of ships.
Objective:\n\n • Recognize the general arrangements on ship dimensions.

Objectives: 
 

• Recalls what is meant by 'panting' and states which part of the ship is affected
 • Recalls what is meant by 'pounding 'or 'slamming' and states which part of the ship is affected
 • Comprehends stresses caused by localized loading
Objective: \n\n • Recalls the types of materials that are used in the construction of a ship

Objectives: \n • Identify the purpose of bilge keels and how they are attached to the ship\'s side • Explain why transverse bulkheads have vertical corrugations and for－and－aftbulkheads have horizontal ones\n
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=f20mMuOclR0 – Bilge keels meaning

Objectives: 

 • Identify what are the fittings found on deck
 • Able to recall the construction and attachment to the deck of tension winches and comprehends how they are used
 • Distinguish the action of the rudder in steering a ship
 • Know the purpose of the rudder carrier and pintles
Objectives:\n\n • Identify proper use of knots ,splices and stoppers, • Able to label different techniques on knot tying
Reset 3D Object
See 3D Parts Details
Rotate View
Drag 3D Object
You can reset the assembled parts of the ship using this button.
Through this button you can able to see further information about the parts of the ship.
Upon clicking this button user can able to rotate the view of the ship while on simulation.
This button will allow user to drag each part of the ship while simulating.
Anchor
A device or iron so shaped to grip the bottom and holds a vessel at anchor by the anchor chain.
Bow Thruster
Bow thruster or stern thruster is a transversal propulsion device built into, or mounted to, either the bow or stern, of a shipor boat, to make it more manoeuvrable.
Bulbous Bow

Bulbous bow - is a protruding bulb at the bow (or front) of a ship just below the waterline. The bulb modifies the way the water flows around the hull, reducing drag and thus increasing speed, range, fuel efficiency, and stability.
Ship Crane
A large, tall machine used for moving heavy objects, typically by suspending them from a projecting arm or beam.
Deck of the ship

is a permanent covering over a compartment or a hull of a ship. On a boat or ship, the primary or upper deck is the horizontal structure which forms the \'roof\' for the hull, which both strengthens the hull and serves as the primary working surface. Vessels often have more than one level both within the hull and in the superstructure above the primary deck which are similar to the floors of a multi-storey building, and which are also referred to as decks, as are specific compartments and decks built over specific areas of the superstructure.
Forecastle

Refers to the upper deck of a sailing ship forward of the foremast, or the forward part of a ship with the sailors living quarters. Related to the latter meaning is the phrase before the mast which denotes anything related to ordinary sailors, as opposed to a ship\'s officers.
Funnel
is the smokestack or chimney on a ship used to expel boiler steam and smoke or engine exhaust. They are also commonly referred to as stacks.
Hull

Hull is the watertight body of a ship or boat. Above the hull is the superstructure and/or deckhouse, where present. The line where the hull meets the water surface is called the waterline. The structure of the hull varies depending on the vessel type.
Main Deck
Is a Principal Deck of a Vessel
Marine diesel engine

Marine diesel engine (also known as a compression-ignition or \'CI\' engine) is an internal combustion engine in which ignition of the fuelthat has been injected into the combustion chamber is initiated by the high temperature which a gas achieves when greatly compressed (adiabatic compression)
Marine Gas Turbine

Marine gas turbine, also called a combustion turbine, is a type of internal combustion engine. It has an upstream rotating compressor coupled to a downstream turbine, and a combustion chamber in between.
Marine Steam engine
Marine Steam engine that uses the expansion or rapid condensation of steam to generate power.
Propeller

is a type of fan that transmits power by converting rotational motion into thrust. A pressure difference is produced between the forward and rear surfaces of the air foil-shaped blade, and a fluid (such as air or water) is accelerated behind the blade.
Rudder

is a primary control surface used to steer aship, boat, submarine, hovercraft, aircraft, or other conveyance that moves through a fluid medium (generally air or water). On an aircraft the rudder is used primarily to counter adverse yaw and p-factor and is not the primary control used to turn the airplane.
Shaft

is a mechanical component for transmitting torque and rotation, usually used to connect other components of a drive train that cannot be connected directly because of distance or the need to allow for relative movement between them.
Stern

is the back or aft-most part of aship or boat, technically defined as the area built up over the sternpost, extending upwards from the counter rail to the Taff rail. The stern lies opposite of the bow, the foremost part of a ship.
